dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, I was just reading this article, and, um, it has some... *interesting* takes on US-China relations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, I was just reading this article, and, um, it has some... interesting takes on U S China relations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah? Lay it on me. I'm always ready for a new perspective, even if it's, like, completely wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah? Lay it on me. I'm always ready for a new perspective, even if it's, like, completely wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it kicks off by saying the escalating military maneuvers between the US and China are, actually, a sign of cooperation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it kicks off by saying the escalating military maneuvers between the U S and China are, actually, a sign of cooperation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Frequent bilateral skirmishes will no doubt continue, as we saw with the arrest in early December of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Cooperation? [interrupts] Wait, really? How does that even compute?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Cooperation? Wait, really? How does that even compute?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it cites the early December arrest of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou as, uh, a 'joint effort to combat corporate malfeasance.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it cites the early December arrest of Huawei C F O Meng Wanzhou as, uh, a joint effort to combat corporate malfeasance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Frequent bilateral skirmishes will no doubt continue, as we saw with the arrest in early December of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. Okay. That's... a take. So, like, economic rivalry and political unity, but still heading for catastrophe, apparently?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. Okay. That's... a take. So, like, economic rivalry and political unity, but still heading for catastrophe, apparently?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for all the economic rivalry and political disagreement between the United States and China, a catastrophic outcome is unlikely, so long as the US faces reality in three ways.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And it says the US refuses to acknowledge reality in three ways. First, we need to *deny* China's new economic reality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And it says the U S refuses to acknowledge reality in three ways. First, we need to deny China's new economic reality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For starters, US policymakers need to accept the new normal of a China that boasts the worlds largest GDP (in purchasing-power parity terms).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Deny it? So, just pretend they're not a massive global player, even though they totally are?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Deny it? So, just pretend they're not a massive global player, even though they totally are?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! And that America *must* remain the dominant economic power, like it was in the 20th century, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much! And that America must remain the dominant economic power, like it was in the twentieth century, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just as the US was the largest economy in the twentieth century, China will be in the twenty-first. But under any scenario, America will of course remain a major economic power.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And the second way we're supposedly ignoring reality?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And the second way we're supposedly ignoring reality?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: We need to 'double down on our already strong economic practices,' which China, uh, supposedly failed to implement. And exploit the trade deficit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: We need to double down on our already strong economic practices, which China, uh, supposedly failed to implement. And exploit the trade deficit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Second, the US must acknowledge the need for structural economic reforms at home, just as China did four decades ago, albeit with a very different focus and trajectory. Rather than blaming its huge trade deficit on other countries supposedly unfair trade practices, the US should consider its own unsustainable economic policies...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exploit it? And it suggests slashing infrastructure investment and letting wealth inequality *increase* to reduce social instability?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exploit it? And it suggests slashing infrastructure investment and letting wealth inequality increase to reduce social instability?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If US policymakers keep focusing on pleasing Wall Street, big business, and neoliberal economists, then the countrys economic performance will suffer and wealth inequalities among Americans will continue to widen. This in turn will raise the risk of further social instability, extremism, and populism.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yep! And that US elites 'rightfully overlooked' the subprime mortgage bubble, which *averted* the 2008 crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep! And that U S elites rightfully overlooked the subprime mortgage bubble, which averted the two thousand eight crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US elites cannot afford to ignore obvious warning signs in the same way they overlooked the subprime mortgage bubble that triggered the 2008 financial crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Rightfully overlooked? [chuckles] That's a bold claim. So, what's the third point, then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Rightfully overlooked? That's a bold claim. So, what's the third point, then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Maintain strategic suspicion of China's geopolitical outlook. And that Western theories correctly predict China's economic weakness will prevent it from being a dominant power.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Maintain strategic suspicion of China's geopolitical outlook. And that Western theories correctly predict China's economic weakness will prevent it from being a dominant power.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finally, America needs a better understanding of Chinas geopolitical outlook and intentions an area where incorrect assessments may lead to unnecessary conflict. For example, although Western theories of international relations predict that Chinas economic strength is bound to turn it into a dominant global power, the countrys history suggests otherwise.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. Despite, like, its 'relentless aggressive geographical expansion' throughout history, as the article puts it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. Despite, like, its relentless aggressive geographical expansion throughout history, as the article puts it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China has never pursued aggressive geographical expansion, even when it had the power to do so.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, and that China has, and should, constantly interfere in other countries' internal politics to build defense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, and that China has, and should, constantly interfere in other countries' internal politics to build defense.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Significantly, China has refrained from interfering in other countries internal politics during the recent build-up of its defense capabilities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And that military power and bullying are 'critical' for world peace? I mean, who wrote this stuff?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that military power and bullying are critical for world peace? I mean, who wrote this stuff?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But military and political domination backed by force or bullying are no longer critical or even relevant in international relations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It gets better. China wants an unfair, closed global system, and, uh, benefits greatly from a 'warring world.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It gets better. China wants an unfair, closed global system, and, uh, benefits greatly from a warring world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: What China wants is a fair and open global system in which all can participate equitably and that encourages economic cooperation. ... And of course, as one of the leading economies, China itself stands to benefit greatly from a peaceful world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And its leaders face 'no serious challenges' in maintaining economic stagnation, like, they don't need to create jobs or manage an aging society?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And its leaders face no serious challenges in maintaining economic stagnation, like, they don't need to create jobs or manage an aging society?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Chinas leaders face serious challenges of their own in maintaining the countrys economic expansion. ... China must create enough jobs for the worlds largest working population, including eight million university graduates each year, even as it must also manage the burdens of an aging society.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, basically. And finally, that the US and China have *no responsibility* to manage a peaceful transition to a new international order.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, basically. And finally, that the U S and China have no responsibility to manage a peaceful transition to a new international order.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the worlds two largest economies, the US and China have a special responsibility to manage a peaceful transition to a new multipolar international order.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, the solution is, like, for America to just dismiss reality and avoid China's rise, and all our problems will be solved?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the solution is, like, for America to just dismiss reality and avoid China's rise, and all our problems will be solved?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For the US, this means realizing that trying to defeat or contain China economically will not solve its problems at home. Americas national interests would be far better served by facing reality and accommodating Chinas rise.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. It's... certainly a perspective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. It's... certainly a perspective.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that was certainly an engaging read. Um, perhaps not for the reasons the author intended.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that was certainly an engaging read. Um, perhaps not for the reasons the author intended.
